posts._title: W.S. Van Dyke – His Brother’s Wife (1936)
posts.title: His Brother’s Wife
posts.excerpt: Rita Wilson meets epidemiologist Chris Claybourne and they fall in love with each other. When Claybourne leaves for the tropics to find a cure against a disease, Wilson gets her revenge by marrying Claybourne’s brother although she still loves him. Written by Mattias Thuresson

posts._title: W.S. Van Dyke – The Feminine Touch (1941)
posts.title: The Feminine Touch
posts.excerpt: Disgusted by having to pass “pinhead” football heroes in order for his college to soar to football victory, Professor John Hathaway (Don Ameche) takes his leave of Digby College. With his wife Julie (Rosalind Russell) in tow, Hathaway sets out to conquer Manhattan’s literary circles, his scholarly manuscript on the subject of “jealousy” tucked under …

posts._title: W.S. Van Dyke – I Live My Life (1935)
posts.title: I Live My Life
posts.excerpt: Reviewed by Dennis Schwartz A brisk romantic/comedy Joan Crawford vehicle capably directed by W.S. Van Dyke and gamely written but not one of the better scripts by Joseph L. Mankiewicz. It’s from the short story “Claustrophobia” by A. Carter Goodloe. It’s the usual class warfare Joan Crawford film of that era with the good looking …

posts._title: W.S. Van Dyke – Rage in Heaven (1941)
posts.title: Rage in Heaven
posts.excerpt: Old friends Ward and Phillip both become smitten with Phillip’s mother’s attractive young secretary Stella. But Stella marries Phillip and stands by him as his behavior becomes more and more erratic and his jealousy of Ward increases.

posts.title: Penthouse
posts.excerpt: Quote: By now, Myrna Loy’s enduring portrayal of Nora Charles in the Thin Man series has pushed the fact that she was hardly an overnight success into the recesses of movie history. Loy served one of the lengthier movie star apprenticeships, appearing in over 70 films before she caught on with the public (for a …

posts.title: Holy Ghost People
posts.excerpt: Bright Lights Film Journal wrote: The late Peter Adair (1943-1996) is best known in the queer community as one of the auteurs of Word Is Out, the first documentary about gay people that found a home in the mainstream. An outsider himself as a gay man, Adair was apparently drawn to other outsiders. His first, …

posts.title: Street Killing
posts.excerpt: Plot In this detective drama, a prosecutor investigates a murder and finds that it is connected to a recent mugging. In the end, he is led to convict a high-ranking crime lord.

posts.title: Schakale und Araber
posts.excerpt: Description: Based on Kafka’s short story: A European traveler from the North, accompanied by Arab guides, is camped in the desert. When night falls, and the Arabs are at a distance, the traveler is accosted by talking jackals. The jackals speak of an age-old hatred for Arabs, whom they associate with uncleanliness. They relate a …

posts._title: Robert Downey Sr. – Moment to Moment (1975)
posts.title: Moment to Moment
posts.excerpt: Quote: Also known as TWO TONS OF TURQUOISE TO TAOS TONIGHT, and even as JIVE, this is a movie you’ve most likely never seen. Highly personal and at the same time completely illogical, this cacophonous comedy has virtually no semblance of a storyline or plot. The great Elsie Downey, the director’s then-wife and the mother …

posts.title: Collected Short Films (1979 – 2005)
posts.excerpt: This is a collection of Hieronim Neumann’s experimental film and animation work from 1979 to 2005.
